p: Tongue cancer is the most frequent type of malignancy in the oral cavity, and is characterized by remarkable aggressive biological behavior 1- 4. This is partly due to that tongue cancer is comparatively silent and progresses fast from a premalignant state into invasive carcinoma. This feature causes delay in diagnosis and thus leading to poor prognosis 5, 6. Thus, even the currently understanding of cancer development and progression is rapidly increasing, tongue cancer is still a serious health issue in many counties with significantly lower 5-year survival rate in patients 7, 8. Hence, expanding our understanding of the pathophysiological mechanism to develop effective methods for early screening and diagnosis and identification of new therapeutic targets are urgently required for tongue cancer.
